ARABIC: تَنزِعُ ٱلنَّاسَ كَأَنَّهُمْ أَعْجَازُ نَخْلٍ مُّنقَعِرٍ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: It plucked up men like uprooted stumps.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: Which snatched away men as though they were palm trees pulled out by the roots.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: which tore people away and hurled them as though they were trunks of uprooted palm-trees.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: which hurled people around like uprooted trunks of palm-trees.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: Smashing down men as if they were uprooted trunks of date palms.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Plucking out men as if they were uprooted stems of date palms.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: Tearing men away as if they were the trunks of palm-trees torn up.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: plucking up men as if they were stumps of uprooted palm-trees.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Sweeping men away as though they were uprooted trunks of palm-trees.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: It swept people away as if they were trunks of uprooted palm trees.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Carrying men away as though they were trunks of palm-trees uprooted.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: knocking down people as if they were trunks of uprooted palm trees.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Plucking out men as if they were roots of palm-trees torn up (from the ground).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Plucking out men as if they were uprooted stems of date-palms.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: and snatched people up as though they were stumps of uprooted palmtrees.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: Plucking the people away, as though they were trunks of uprooted palm-trees.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: Extracting the people as if they were trunks of palm trees uprooted.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [54:20] tearing people away, wrenching them from the holes in the ground in which they had been embedded and flinging them down [to the ground] head first, thereby crushing their necks and severing [their] heads from [their] bodies, as if they were, [while lying] in this mentioned state, trunks of uprooted palm-trees, severed and thrown on the ground — they are likened to palm-trees because of their tallness (nakhlun, ‘palm-trees’, is masculine here but feminine in [sūrat] al-Hāqqa, nakhlun khāwiya, ‘fallen down [or hollow] palm-trees’, [Q. 69:7], in order to harmonise with the end-rhyme of the verses in both instances).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (Sweeping men away as though they were uprooted trunks of palm-trees.
